subject: Writing
title: Maxwell Perkins: The Editor Who Made Legends
description: A fast breakdown of Maxwell Perkins: The Editor Who Made Legends for builders.

hook.text: F. Scott Fitzgerald, Ernest Hemingway, and Thomas Wolfe had one thing in common: the same editor made them great.

buildup.text: Maxwell Perkins at Scribner's became the most famous editor in publishing history during the 1920s and 1930s.

discovery.text: He cut 90,000 words from Thomas Wolfe's manuscripts and convinced Fitzgerald to rewrite Gatsby's ending.

twist.text: Perkins believed editors should be invisible â€” his name rarely appeared on books, but his mark was on every page.

climax.text: He proved that great publishing requires great editing â€” the best books are shaped, not just written.

punchline.text: Behind every literary legend stood the same invisible hand.
